<h1>Our research</h1>  
  
<body>  
<style> body {text-align: justify} </style> 

Currently, our lab is focusing on two main lines of research: 
  
<div style= "float:left;top: -0px;position: relative; padding:10px; width:500px; margin: 10px 10px">
![Phylogeny of Myrteae -- in preparation with V. Staggemeier et al.](images/myrteae.jpg){}

</div>  
<p style="text-align:center;">
<font size="4"> **Systematics, evolution, and ecology of Myrtales** </font>
</p>
<style> body {text-align: justify} </style> 
  
We are interested in understanding the evolution of plants in poorly studied tropical areas and groups, mainly focused on lineages within the order Myrtales (guavas, pomegranates, cloves). We have several collaborators based in Brazil and the UK working together on this line of research and there is plenty of opportunity for international collaboration and fieldwork for prospective students and postdocs.

  
<div><img src="images/blank.jpg" width="100%" align="center"></div>    
  
<div style= "float:right;top: -0px;position: relative; padding:10px; width:500px; margin: 10px 10px">
![Linking seed dispersal traits and climatic niche evolution in plants - modified from Vasconcelos et al. (2021) J. Biogeography](images/biogeo.jpg){}
</div> 
<p style="text-align:center;">
<font size="4"> **Discovering the rules of plant biogeography using a trait-based approach** </font>  
</p> 
  
Trait-environment correlation analyses are ways to discover general patterns in plant biogeography by quantifying to what extent unrelated lineages have similar evolutionary responses to a given environment
In this line, we use natural history collections and trait characterization tools to build comprehensive datasets of occurrence points and functional traits. We combine these datasets with molecular phylogenies and phylogenetic comparative methods to quantify trait-environment correlations through flowering plant evolution.
